‚ÄúWhen shared between members of a civic-minded community, trust is the one thing that can keep state power in check ‚Äî unless, of course, we allow ourselves to be manipulated by fear and, in the silence that follows, grow apart from one another.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrust is the glue of the world, the difference between civilization and chaos. It‚Äôs what lets people come together in any kind of cooperative action, from social movements to marriages and markets.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe constant monitoring of a population, [sociology professor Clive] Norris and other scholars note, ‚Äòfosters suspicion,‚Äô undermines ‚Äòcohesion and solidarity,‚Äô and amounts to ‚Äòa slow social suicide.‚Äô In other words: paranoia will destroy you.‚Äù
‚ÄúMassive domestic spying systems ‚Äî like the one Snowden revealed ‚Äî are corrosive to the kind of deep human connections that nourish trust and collaboration.‚Äù

‚ÄúTrust is the basis of all cooperative action in a free society. It‚Äôs the feeling of fellowship that allows people to take risks and grow. It‚Äôs also the underpinning of democracy. And it‚Äôs fragile, easy to undermine.‚Äù

‚ÄúThe story of Snowden‚Äôs box is deeply human, somewhat messy, and more than a little weird. It‚Äôs about a brief moment when strangers worked together to build an underground railroad for secrets‚Äîa high-stakes endeavor that relied, more than anything, on bonds of trust.‚Äù

Adapted from The Care Crisis: What Caused It and How Can We End It? by Emma Dowling https://t.co/Zaa6mGxTsR

It is painfully obvious that massive economic disparities and major political power imbalances are the root of our  predicament. Can something so seemingly fragile as care be powerful enough to transform
such forces?

Why is the responsibility for
ensuring the wellbeing of the elderly, vulnerable and frail being handed to private equity companies, US hedge funds and international real estate investors, whose entire business model is designed to maximise profit, whatever the cost?

Since the financial crash of 2008, the toxic cocktail of recession and austerity has seen those who rely on disability payments suffer inordinately. Elderly people feel lonely and isolated, while their carers are overburdened and underpaid.

Adapted from Grand Hotel Abyss: The Lives of the Frankfurt School. 
https://t.co/Krxal6Y9xb
"Barricades are useless against those who administer the bomb."

For Adorno, the New Left postured as anti-authoritarian but replicated the repressive structures they sought to overthrow. Activists had borrowed the revolutionary tactics that worked in the past, but which in 1969 could only be irrelevant to any struggle to destroy capitalism.
Adorno's lectures were disrupted by protestors, one of whom wrote on the blackboard: "If Adorno is left in peace, capitalism will never cease."

From its inception in 1923, the Frankfurt School was aloof from party politics and skeptical about political struggle. It had a powerful critique of capitalism's crushing impact on western societies, but was not so good at changing what it critiqued.
That, for many, was the problem with the Frankfurt School: it never stooped to revolution.

Not long before he died in 1969, Theodor Adorno told an interviewer: "I established a theoretical model of thought. How could I have suspected that people would want to implement it with Molotov cocktails?"

The rich could well afford some self-isolation in private cocoons, a rather natural extension of their normal lives.

Self-isolation in a slum is a contradiction in terms.

Prior health issues that weaken defences ‚Äì diabetes, heart conditions, lung disease ‚Äì divide along class lines.

Even the measures taken to turn the tide have reinforced these patterns.

There is one Covid-19 for the poor and another for the rich.

Some have access to excellent health care. Others could only dream of sanitisers and soap, let alone insurance and hospitals equipped with brand-new ventilators.

Adapted from Automation and the Future of Work
by Aaron Benanav. 

Mike Davis calls it ‚ÄúA powerful and persuasive explanation of why capitalism can‚Äôt create jobs or generate incomes for a majority of humanity.‚Äù

https://t.co/pr2ew4q90N
If neither technological advancement nor technocratic reform leads to a just world, then it is only the pressure of social movements that can bring it about.
It's easy to see how over the long term, the COVID-19 recession will accelerate what are by now long-unfolding trends of rising economic insecurity and inequality.
Aaron Benanav argues that the resurgence of automation discourse today is a response to a real trend unfolding across the world: there are simply too few jobs for too many people.

Would we be able to adapt our institutions to realize the dream of human freedom that a new age of intelligent machines might make possible? Or would that dream turn out to be a nightmare of mass technological unemployment?
What would human beings do in a largely automated future?
